---
date: '2025-10-21'
modified_time: 2025-10-21 13:39:50-04:00
published_time: 2025-10-21 13:36:51-04:00
source_url: https://www.whitehouse.gov/articles/2025/10/white-house-ballroom-proud-presidential-legacy/
tags: articles
title: White House Ballroom Continues Proud Presidential Legacy
---
 
In the latest instance of manufactured outrage, unhinged leftists and
their Fake News allies are clutching their pearls over President Donald
J. Trump’s visionary addition of a grand, privately funded ballroom to
the White House — a bold, necessary addition that echoes the storied
history of improvements and additions from commanders-in-chief to keep
the executive residence as a beacon of American excellence.

**FACT: For more than a century, U.S. Presidents have been renovating,
expanding, and modernizing the White House to meet the needs of the
present day.**

-   In 1902, President Theodore Roosevelt
    [built](https://www.whitehousehistory.org/questions/has-the-white-house-ever-been-renovated-or-changed#:~:text=1902%20commemorates%20the%20Theodore%20Roosevelt%20renovation%20which%20modernized%20the%20White%20House%20for%20the%20twentieth%20century%20and%20established%20the%20West%20Wing%20as%20the%20new%20executive%20office%20space%20for%20the%20president%20and%20their%20staff.)
    the West Wing — replacing expansive greenhouses constructed during
    the Jefferson Administration and establishing the modern day
    executive office wing with a “[classically leaning
    design](https://www.architecturaldigest.com/story/white-house-renovations-timeline#1902-a-classical-renovation-courtesy-of-roosevelt:~:text=Two%20decades%20later,of%20modern%20times.%E2%80%9D)”
    — along with a [colonial
    garden](https://www.whitehousehistory.org/the-west-garden) and [East
    Terrace](https://archives.whitehousehistory.org/fotoweb/archives/5017-Digital-Archives/Main%20Index/Views/372.jpg.info),
    which eventually became the East Wing.
-   In 1909, President William Howard Taft [remodeled and
    expanded](https://www.history.com/articles/white-house-renovations-history-photos#:~:text=Roosevelt%20had%20his%20own%20office%20built%20in%20the%20main%20residence%2C%20but%20it%20was%20rectangular.%20President%20William%20Howard%20Taft%20remodeled%20and%20expanded%20the%20West%20Wing%20in%201909%20to%20create%20the%20Oval%20Office%2C%20now%20an%20iconic%20symbol%20of%20presidential%20power.)
    the West Wing, which included construction of the first Oval Office.
-   In 1913, President Woodrow Wilson
    [demolished](https://www.whitehousehistory.org/the-west-garden#:~:text=The%20first%20Mrs,John%20F.%20Kennedy.)
    the colonial garden, modernizing it with a rose garden.
-   In 1927, President Calvin Coolidge
    [oversaw](https://www.whitehousehistory.org/photos/photo-4-15) the
    renovation of the upper floors and attic of the White House.
-   In 1929, President Herbert Hoover
    [remodeled](https://www.nytimes.com/1929/06/30/archives/engineer-hoover-inspects-blueprints-for-his-offices.html)
    the West Wing, including reconstruction work in the basement level
    and remodeling the first floor; after a fire on Christmas Eve, the
    West Wing was repaired and
    [reopened](https://www.whitehousehistory.org/videos/the-1929-west-wing-fire-and-reconstruction)
    in 1930.
-   In 1934, President Franklin D. Roosevelt
    [overhauled](%20President%20Franklin%20D.%20Roosevelt%20increased%20the%20office%20area%20of%20a%20now%20permanent%20office%20wing%20from%2015,000%20to%2040,000%20square%20feet.%20A%20%22penthouse%22%20story%20and%20an%20enlarged%20subterranean%20office%20area%20with%20a%20light%20well%20were%20built.%20The%20Oval%20Office%20was%20relocated%20to%20the%20West%20Wing’s%20southeast%20corner-its%20present%20location-to%20overlook%20the%20Wilson%20Rose%20Garden.)
    the West Wing, adding a second floor, a larger basement, and a
    [swimming
    pool](https://www.whitehousehistory.org/photos/fdrs-swimming-pool),
    and relocating the Oval Office to its current location; in 1942,
    President Roosevelt
    [constructed](https://www.history.com/articles/white-house-renovations-history-photos#:~:text=The%20East%20Wing%20wasn%E2%80%99t%20built%20until%201942%20and%20was%20originally%20constructed%20to%20cover%20up%20an%20underground%20bunker%20that%20would%20protect%20the%20president%20and%20his%20staff%20from%20an%20enemy%20attack%20during%20World%20War%20II.)
    the East Wing.
-   In 1948, President Harry Truman
    [undertook](https://www.architecturaldigest.com/story/white-house-renovations-timeline#1902-a-classical-renovation-courtesy-of-roosevelt:~:text=Under%20the%20Truman,Association%20notes.)
    a “total reconstruction” of the White House’s interior, expanding
    its foundation and footprint — preserving
    [only](https://www.whitehousehistory.org/galleries/the-white-house-is-falling-down#:~:text=Early%20in%201948,dismantling%20the%20interior.)
    its exterior walls.
-   In 1962, President John F. Kennedy
    [constructed](https://www.cnn.com/2025/08/10/politics/gallery/a-history-of-the-white-house-rose-garden#:~:text=But%20President%20John,end%20of%201962.)
    the modern Rose Garden.
-   In 1970, President Nixon
    [converted](https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/history/life/pressbriefingroom.html#:~:text=Nearly%2040%20years,to%20outdoor%20events.)
    the swimming pool into the press briefing room; in 1973, he
    [added](https://www.history.com/articles/white-house-renovations-history-photos#:~:text=Every%20president%20since%201952%20has%20made%20their%20own%20small%20changes%20and%20additions%E2%80%94Richard%20Nixon%20installed%20a%20one%2Dlane%20bowling%20alley%20in%201973%2C%20for%20example%2C%20and%20Michelle%20Obama%20created%20the%20White%20House%20Kitchen%20Garden.)
    a bowling alley in the basement.
-   In 1975, President Gerald Ford
    [installed](https://www.fordforum.org/observer-essays/fords-pool) an
    outdoor swimming pool on the South Grounds,
    [financed](https://www.whitehousehistory.org/a-pool-for-the-president#:~:text=Ultimately%2C%20Ford%20spent,7)
    entirely by private donations.
-   In 1993, President Bill Clinton
    [undertook](https://clintonwhitehouse6.archives.gov/1993/11/1993-11-22-press-information-on-white-house-restorations.html)
    a restoration and refurbishment of the Executive Mansion.
-   In 2009, President Barack Obama
    [resurfaced](https://obamawhitehouse.archives.gov/interactive-tour/basketball-court)
    the south-grounds tennis court into a basketball court and
    [added](https://www.nps.gov/places/000/white-house-kitchen-garden.htm)
    the White House Kitchen Garden on the South Lawn.
-   In 2020, President Trump and the First Lady
    [completed](https://trumpwhitehouse.archives.gov/briefings-statements/first-lady-melania-trump-announces-completion-new-white-house-tennis-pavilion/)
    a new White House tennis pavilion, refurbishing the White House
    Tennis Court and Grandchildren’s Garden, as well as constructing a
    new building.

Now, in 2025, President Trump is carrying forward that legacy, breaking
ground on a [grand
ballroom](https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefings-statements/2025/07/the-white-house-announces-white-house-ballroom-construction-to-begin/)
— a transformative addition that will significantly increase the White
House’s capacity to host major functions honoring world leaders, foreign
nations, and other dignitaries.

## **White House construction projects through the years:**
